name: Akhal Teke
Temperament/Personality: Active, loyal, spirited, intelligent, gentle, sensitive
Physical Characteristics: A refined head, straight or fairly convex profile, long ears, almond-shaped eyes, long, lightly muscled back, upright neck, flat croup, sloping shoulders, sparse mane and tail
Colors: Palomino, golden buckskin, perlino, cremello, chestnut, bay, black, gray; horses with cream gene have a metallic sheen
Common Uses: As a sport-horse for dressage, eventing, endurance riding, racing, show jumping
Health: May be affected by genetic diseases including naked foal syndrome, hereditary cryptorchidism, Wobbler syndrome, Osteochondritis dissecans, Degenerative suspensory ligament desmitis
Gaited: Yes; smooth, elastic strides, walk, trot, canter
Popular Traits: Endurance, resilience, toughness, ability to survive in harsh native conditions, can live without much water or food
Feeding/Diet: A sparse, high-protein diet with grass, alfalfa, pellets of mutton-fat, barley, dry lucerne
Breed Registry/Association: International Association of Akhal-Teke Breeding (MAAK), Akhal Teke Association of America

name: Andalusian
Other Names: Spanish Horse, Pura Raza Española, PRE
Common Uses: General riding, Endurance, Dressage, Horse shows, Performances
Popular Traits: Beautiful, high emotional intelligence, low maintenance, very strong, excellent movements during walking/running
Feeding/Diet: General horse diet including hay, grass, grains, etc.
Physical Traits/Description: The profile is typically convex with a large, sculpted head having bright eyes and a kind expression; the neck is arched with a short-coupled torso, resting atop muscular and round hindquarters; the cannon bones are short, while both the mane and tail are flowing
Coat Colors: Traditional common colors were bay, black, grey, and chestnut, but they were also found in perlino, buckskin, palomino, and dun. Presently, mostly found in bay and grey; buckskin, pearl, and cremello are extremely rare
Health Problems: Needs regular grooming to stay healthy; some cases of skin cancer have been reported
Type: Riding horse, Show horse, Utility horse
Associations, Registries & Breed Standar:
International Andalusian & Lusitano Horse Association
Association of the Foundation Andalusian Horse

name: Arabian
Common Uses: Enhancement of other bloodlines, Racing, Show, Pleasure riding, Work
Popular Traits: Quick, multi-talented, efficient, excellent movements, good in jumping, easily trainable, sturdy
Feeding/Diet: General horse diet including hay, grass, grains, etc.
Country of Origin:
Unknown;
Developed in the Middle East (especially, in the Arabian peninsula)
Coat Colors: Bay, black, chestnut, and gray are traditional colors; occasionally white, sabino, or rabicano patterns
Health Problems: At least, six known genetic disorders have been reported, viz. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID), Lavender Foal Syndrome (LFS), Cerebellar abiotrophy (CA or CCA), Occipital Atlanto-Axial Malformation (OAAM), Equine Juvenile Epilepsy (or Juvenile Idiopathic Epilepsy), and Guttural Pouch Tympany (GPT), with the first two being conditionally fatal
Type: Riding horse, Sport horse, Show horse, Work horse
Physical Traits: The profile is slightly concave, massive, compact and well-proportioned with a refined, wedge-shaped head ending in a short muzzle bearing large nostrils, a pair of expressive eyes and curved ears; the arched neck has a clean and refined throatlatch; the back part is short, while the tail is set high
Associations and Registries:
World Arabian Horse Organization
Arabian Horse Association (USA)
The Arab Horse Society (UK)
Emirates Arabian Horse Society
Arabian Horse World
Arabian Jockey Club
New Zealand Arab Horse Breeders’ Society
Arabian Horse DataSource
Arabian Horse Society of Australia
Canadian Arabian Horse Registry
Arab Horse Society
Arab Horse Society of South Africa
National Arabian Horse Society of Russia (NOAL)
The Pyramid Society
Finnish Arabian Horse Society

name: Belgian
Other Names: Belgian Horse, Belgian heavy horse, Belgian heavy draft, Belgisch Trekpaard, Brabant Trekpaard, Brabander, Brabancon, Cheval de trait Beige
Colors: Chestnut or sorrel and roan with snow white markings on the legs, face, mane, and tail
Health:
Subjected to more health issues than other breeds. Common diseases are
JEB (Junctional Epidermolysis Bullosa), a genetic disorder where newborn foals may lose a lot of their skin and show other abnormalities.
Chronic Progressive Lymphedema (swelling, thickening or hyperkeratosis and fibrosis of the distal limbs)
Mud fever
Azoturia
Popular Traits: Hardy, and strong
Temperament and Personality: Calm, docile, kind, willing, steady and easy-to-handle. Foals are very playful
Physical Description: Light and square head; straight or slightly concave profile; short, muscular neck; powerful loins; short, broad back; heavily muscled gaskins; medium-sized hooves; lean and strong legs with some amount of feathering;
What are they used for: For draft works like ploughing, logging, pulling sleighs, hitches, and carriages, as well as for pleasure riding, show jumping, dressage, and endurance.
Diet (How much does a Belgian Draft hors: Being a draft horse it needs a good amount of hay and grain

name: Caspian
Common Uses: Dressage, jumping, mounted athletics, racing, pleasure riding, show, harness racing, competition, scurry driving
Popular Traits: Highly intelligent, multi-talented, easy trainability, adaptable to harness, easy to keep, skilled movements (sure-footed with long low strides)
Coat Colors:
Common colors include black, chestnut, gray, and bay;
piebald or skewbald (pinto) are not considered in the breed standards
Health Problems: Otherwise a healthy breed, some individuals have been reported to have suffered from laminitis, which often happens from under exercising and overfeeding
Type: Sport horse, Show horse, Riding horse
Physical Traits: The stature is relatively short, with a small skull having a vaulted forehead; the coat is fine and thin, while the neck is long and arched and the shoulders are sloped; the hindquarters are muscular and proportionate with tough hooves; the mane and the high set tail are luxurious and long
Associations and Registries:
Caspian Horse Society, UK
Caspian Horse Society of the Americas
Behavioral Characteristics: Gentle, kind, alert, spirited, adaptable, eager, friendly
Care:
Feeding/Diet: Needs minimum forage; requires little or no grain supplement
(minimum supplements high in sugar or carbohydrates is essential)
Activities: Needs frequent exercise and attention

name: Exmoor
Physical Characteristics: Stocky, sturdily built, deep chest, broad back and croup, short legs, hard hooves, relatively large lower jaws with an extra tooth, large head with small ears, large, pronounced eyes; a winter coat with a wooly underlayer and an upper layer consisting of longer hairs, thick, long mane, and tail
Colors: Brown or dark bay with black points, mealy or buff markings around the muzzle, eyes, flanks and underbelly; white markings are not allowed
Height (size): 11.1-12.3 hands (114-130 cm, 45-51 inches); some may reach 13.2 hands
Common Uses: For agility, long-distance riding, showing, and driving; also for conservation grazing and tending livestock; previously used as pit ponies
Health: A healthy breed; resistant to common equine diseases
Popular Traits: Endurance, balanced appearance, strength, hooded eye, short coarse hairs on top of the tail
Feeding/Diet: Grasses, heather, gorse, rushes
Ancestors: Wild horses like Tarpan and Pottok may have had influenced the Exmoor ponies
Breed Registry/Association: The Exmoor Pony Society – breed standard

name: Finnhorse
Common Uses: General riding, dressage, transportation, mounted-athletics, jumping, work activities
Popular Traits: Multi-talented, easy trainability, durable
Feeding/Diet: A normal diet including hay, grass, grains, etc.
Coat Colors:
Chestnut (most common), chestnut with flaxen dilution, grey, bay, black, roan, palomino, silver dapple, skewbald pinto;
often have white markings on head and legs
Type: Riding Horse, Sports Horse, Show Horse, Work Horse
Physical Traits: Generally solid build; dry and strongly-muscled, with good hooves and strong bone, but physique varies considerably because of their different body types

name: French Trotter
Physical Characteristics: Slightly large head, wide eyes, deep, broad chest, prominent breastbone, straight limbs, strong hooves, strong back and muscular quarters
Colors: Chestnut, brown, black, bay and gray (very rare)
Health: Healthy with no known breed-related problems, though owners should ensure a healthy living and regular vet checkup
Gaited: Maintains a diagonal two beat trotting gait
Popular Traits: Intelligence, endurance, agility and determination.
Feeding/Diet: Normally their diet includes grain and hay
Ancestors: Norman stock horse, English Thoroughbred, American standardbred, and Hackney
Height (Size): 15 to 17 hands (60 to 65 inches; 152 to 165 cm)

name: Hanoverian
Temperament/Personality: Bold, sensible, intelligent, willing, trainable, determined, disciplined, docile, calm, level-headed
Physical Characteristics: A powerful, muscular body; a strong back, sturdy limbs; and athletic movement
Colors: Black, bay, gray, and chestnut are common; cremello, palomino, buckskin, and excessively white horses are not allowed
Height (size): 15.3-17.2 hands (160-178 cm, 63-70 inches); most horses measure 16-16.2 hands (163-168 cm, 64-66 inches)
Weight: A matured Hanoverian can weigh around 1,400 lbs (635 kg)
Health: Hanoverians with the brand usually have a sound health. However, osteochondrosis can affect their joints; it can contribute to Wobbler disease, navicular syndrome, and osteoarthrosis
Popular Traits: Beauty, grace, athleticism, strength, even temperament
Feeding/Diet: Good quality forage including fresh grass and dried hay; grain mixtures can be given to complement the forage; fresh supply of water should be available
Ancestors: Thoroughbred, Cleveland Bay, Holsteiner, Prussian, Andalusian, Neapolitan, and Mecklenburg horses
Common Use: Previously a carriage horse; now used for General Riding, Competitive Dressage, Show Jumping and Hunting, Eventing, and Equestrian Sports

name: Icelandic
Other Names: Islenzki hesturinn, Icelandic pony, Iceland Tolter, Icelandic toelter horse
Temperament/Personality: Patient, uncomplicated, spirited, adaptable, friendly, easy going
Physical Characteristics: Well-proportioned head, straight profile, wide forehead; short, muscular neck with a broad base, broad and low withers, deep chest, slightly sloping and muscular shoulders, long back, short, muscular, and broad croup, strong legs, short pasterns, long cannon bones, full tail and mane
Colors: Gray, chestnut, black, palomino, pinto, roan, dun, bay
Common Uses: Traditional sheepherding, showing, leisure riding, and racing
Health: No known diseases specific to the breed; the Icelandic government has taken strict measures for their protection
Gaited: Yes; walk, trot, canter/gallop; a four-beat ambling gait called tölt, and a smooth pace called flugskeið, skeið, or “flying pace”
Popular Traits: Unique gaits, sturdily built, amiable disposition, ability to carry weight on rough terrain, easy to maintain
Feeding/Diet: A mix of alfalfa, soya meal, linseed, flaked maize, vitamin supplement
Ancestors: Faroe and Yakut ponies; Fjord, Mongolian, and Nordlandshest horses
Breed Registry/Association: The Icelandic Horse Society of Great Britain, United States Icelandic Horse Conference

name: Lusitano
Common Uses: General riding, Show, Performances, Bullfighting
Popular Traits: Multi-talented, athletic, elegant springy action, strong presence, can display a high degree of flexion in hind legs, intelligent, fast learner, submissive temperament
Feeding/Diet: General horse diet including hay, grass, grains, etc.
Coat Colors: Gray, bay and chestnut are most common. However, black, dun and palomino are also found
Type: Sport horse, Riding horse, Show horse
Physical Traits: The profile is convex with a deep, short-coupled body and a large head, almond-shaped eyes, sturdy, arched neck, a sloped croup and short cannon bones; the mane and the low-set tail is dense and graceful
Associations and Registries:
International Andalusian & Lusitano Horse Association
APSL (Portugal)
Breed Standard
Behavioral Characteristics: Noble, generous, ardent, gentle, enduring, courageous, friendly, kind

name: Mangalarga Paulista
Common Uses: Jumping, dressage, work, endurance, general riding
Popular Traits: Smooth-gaited, multi-talented, excellent in jumping, easily trainable, durable
Feeding/Diet: General horse diet including hay, grass, grains, etc.
Coat Colors: Black, white, brown, bay, gray, chestnut, dun, buckskin, palomano, perlino, cremello, roan, champagne, and grullo
Health Problems: Healthy in general; no known breed-specific issues
Type: Cattle Horse, Riding Horse, Sports Horse, Transportation Horse
Physical Traits: Have a straight profile with the head being triangular; the eyes are large and dark while the ears are erect with the tips turned inwards; the neck is muscular and arched, and the chest is deep and well-built; they have a medium back with straight, long, well-muscled legs

name: Maremmano
Common Uses: Work, general riding, endurance
Popular Traits: Versatile, strong and hardy, easily trainable
Feeding/Diet: General horse diet consisting of hay, grass, grains, vegetables, etc.
Health Problems: The breed is generally healthy. No breed-specific health issues. Owners must ensure to maintain a healthy lifestyle and regular vet checkups
Behavioral Characteristics: Docile disposition, obedient temperament; amiable, loyal, intelligent, easily trainable
Physical Descriptions/Traits: Long, moderately-heavy head, muscular neck getting broad at the base; high, well-muscled withers; full chest with sloping shoulders; short back with a sloping croup; they have solid legs and a sturdy structure with good joints and strong hooves
Movements: Even, energetic trots with long strides

name: Miniature
Common Uses: No particular uses; kept as pets
Popular Traits: Hardy, easy to keep, easily trainable, low maintenance cost
Feeding/Diet: General horse diet including hay, grass, grains, etc.
Coat Colors: Common colors include black, gray, white, pintaloosa, pinto
Health Problems: Prone to pick up a few issues including dwarfism, eclampsia, hyperlipemia, brachygnathism, colic, crowding, prognathism, and obesity
Physical Traits: Despite having a short stature, the body is well-proportioned and strong; has a short head with a sturdy neck and slightly curved back with medium to short mane; the legs are strongly-built while the tail is long and dense

name: Mongolian
Temperament/Personality: Calm, reliable and friendly (after being accustomed to the rider).
Physical Characteristics: Short, stocky build, strong legs, large head, strong and hard hooves
Colors: Dun, Black, Bay, Shun, White, Brown, Roan, Grey, Palomino
Health: Generally healthy with no known breed-related ailments.
Gaited: Yes (Mostly decides his own gait while the rider is engrossed in other chores like tending cattle).  [1]
Popular Traits: Athletic, strong, energetic, requires low maintenance
Feeding/Diet: Mostly eat tall grasses and hay along with foliage, fruit, bark and plants with a rough texture. Drinks less amount of water or even eats snow in winter when in the wild.
Common Use: General riding, hunting, endurance riding, racing, mounted athletics like polo, racing and for work.
Year/Time of Development: Though the exact date of development of these traditional horses has not been known, they gained prominence in the 13th century.
Life Span/ Life Expectancy: 20 to 40 years ( working till they are 18 years old)
Breed Information: Has not yet been recognized by any breed organizations.

name: New Forest Pony
Temperament/Personality: Docile, easy to train, courageous, intelligent
Physical Characteristics: Small head, thickly-furred ears with pointed tips, stocky and muscular body, short back, deep, narrow chest, sloping croup, low-set tail, thick winter coat and mane
Colors: Black, bay/brown, roan, chestnut, dun, gray, and occasionally white; seasonal color changes may occur
Common Uses: Pleasure riding, driving, as show horse, light draft work
Health: The ponies should be vaccinated against tetanus, rhinopneumonitis, and influenza
Popular Traits: Sturdiness, willingness to work, sure-footedness, can live on little food
Feeding/Diet: Grass, hay, small quantity of vitamins and minerals
Ancestors: Connemara, Dartmoor, Fell, Exmoor, New Forest, Highland, and now-extinct Galloway pony

name: Percheron
Physical Characteristics: Head with a straight profile, large eyes, broad forehead, medium-sized ears, deep cheek, strong neck, deep well-laid shoulders, wide chest, strong and short back, wide, deep ribs, clean, heavily-muscled legs and feet
Colors: Gray or black, with partial white markings on heads and legs are allowed in Britain and France; chestnut, bay, and roan are also allowed in the US
Height (size): 15.1-18.1 hands (61-73 inches, 155-185 cm) in France, 16.2-17.3 hands (65-71 inches, 168-180 cm) in the US, more than 16.1 hands (64.4 inches, 164 cm) in Great Britain
Common Uses: Originally used as war horses; pulling stagecoaches and carriages, hauling heavy goods, agriculture, farm work, riding, dressage, show jumping, meat production, crossed with other breeds
Health: Equine Polysaccharide Storage Myopathy (EPSM) and arterial occlusion may affect some horses
Gaited: Yes; straight, bold movement with long free strides
Popular Traits: Good-natured, energetic, willing workers, easy keepers, adapts well to harsh climates and conditions
Feeding/Diet: Forage, including pasture, hay pellets or cubes, vitamin and mineral supplements
Ancestors: Arabian, Oriental, Spanish, Boulonnais, Moorish horses
Breed Registry/Association: Percheron Horse Association of America, Les Haras Nationaux (France), British Percheron Horse Society

name: Shetland
Common Uses: Riding (especially children), dressage, show and pack purposes
Popular Traits: Small size, multi-talented, good in jumping, adaptable, overall docile personality
Coat Colors: Black, bay, dun, roan, brown, chestnut, gray, brown and part-colored
Height/Size:
Up to 11 hands (adult)
(Registered individuals must not exceed 10.2 hands)
Health Problems: Both foals and stallions/mares are sturdy, with no specific diseases
Type: Riding Pony, Show Pony, Guide Pony, Cart pony, Mining pony, Working Pony (both commercial and domestic)
Physical Traits: Short body with a small but well-proportioned head, small and erect ears, dark eyes, and a well-set neck covered by dense, long-hanging mane; the shoulder is sloped, while the legs and feet are short but solid and tough ending in strong hooves (modern American subtypes are more refined)
Associations and Registries:
The Shetland Pony Stud-Book Society (UK)
American Shetland Pony Club (USA)
Behavioral Characteristics/Qualities: Highly intelligent, lively, headstrong, independent, adaptable, affectionate
Diet/Feeding/Drinking: Normal equine diet including hay, grass, grains, etc.

name: Shire
Physical Characteristics: The structure is massive, with a big head, large eyes; the long neck is slightly arched ending in a wide chest and broad shoulders; the legs are muscular with the perfect hocks set for maximum leverage; the back of the legs are covered with dense feathering while the hooves are round and large
Common Uses: General riding, dressage, eventing, pulling hefty goods
Feeding/Diet: General horse diet including hay, grass, grains, etc.
Health Problems: Healthy in general; no specific diseases
Type: Cart Horse, Heavy Draft Horse, Riding Horse, Sports Horse, Show Horse, Parade Horse
Ancestors (Bloodlines): The Great Horse, Packington Blind Horse, Friesan, Flanders
Associations and Registries:
American Shire Horse Association
Breed Standards
Time of Origin: End of 16th to beginning of 17th century

name: Swiss Warmblood
Colors: Black, buckskin, dun, roan, champagne, perlino, cremello, grullo, brown, palomino, gray, chestnut, bay
Health: No know breed specific health problems
Ancestors: Anglo-Norman horse; Yorkshire Coach horse; Holsteiners
Temperament and Personality: Calm, gentle., willing, easy-to-train, loyal, fun loving, well-mannered, alert and intelligent
Physical Description: Small head; straight and slightly convex profile; expressive ears; alert eyes; deep, well-muscled chest; prominent withers; sloping croup; long, hard legs; well-defined tendons; and short cannons
What are they used for: General riding, endurance riding, dressage, hunting

name: Clydesdale
Common Uses: General riding, eventing, show, work
Popular Traits: Multi-talented, excellent in stepping (high steps), easy trainability, durable
Feeding/Diet: General horse diet including hay, grass, grains, etc.
Coat Colors: Bay is the most common, but also black, gray, roan and pinto
Type: Draught Horse, Show Horse, Work Horse (forestry and agriculture), Patrol Horse, Parade Horse
Physical Traits: The structure is large with a straight profile and a handsome head, with stout shoulders and chest, a long, crested neck and high withers; the feet silky feathers on the back and are flat and open that are fitted for walking through hard surfaces (rather than for plowing); the legs are long and well-shaped (with the hind quarters being longer than other draft breeds)

name: Fell Pony
Temperament/Personality: Steady, lively, alert, intelligent and independent
Gaited: Regular, sure-footed with hock and knee action
Popular Traits: Reliable jumpers, sturdy built and feathered legs
Physical Traits: Hardy with a strong flat bone; small head; broad forehead; large nostrils; prominent and intelligent eyes; neatly set ears; proportionate neck length,  moderate crest and sloping shoulders;
Color: Black, brown, Chestnut, bay and Grey, / white marking on or below the hind fetlock ( excess white marking is eligible for registration but discouraged by the breeders)
Health problems: FPS (Fell Pony Syndrome), commonly occurring in the foals of this breed.
Feeding/ diet: Pasture, hay (grass), vitamin supplement, free-choice minerals, and probiotics
Breed registry/Association:
Fell Pony Society
·Fell Pony Society of North America

name: Morgan
Common Uses: Endurance riding, general riding, jumping, racing, competitive trail riding, driving
Popular Traits: Multi-talented (versatile), easy trainability, intelligent, adaptable to harness, easy to keep
Ancestors: Welsh Cob, Thoroughbred, Arabian and Barb
Coat Colors: 12 common coat colors, with the most common ones  including black, chestnut, gray, and piebald
Height/Size: 14.1 to 15.2 hands (adult male and female average)
Health Problems: Normally a healthy breed with no breed-specific problems
Type: Sports horse, Show horse, Trail Riding horse, Pleasure Riding horse, Harness Racing horse
Physical Traits: Has a large body with a deep girth and a straight profile with the head being medium-sized that is tapered down to the muzzle; the neck is upright and graceful, while the shoulder is sloping and is strongly-built while the chest and the back are broad; the legs are well-formed having strong joints with symmetrical hind legs and quarters; the tail is characteristically straight and flowing
Behavioral Characteristics: Versatile, brave, spirited, adaptable, eager, friendly
Care: Needs minimum forage; requires little or no grain supplement

name: Standardbred (US)
Physical Characteristics: Muscular stature with straight, refined head; broad forehead, shallow mouth, large nostrils, well-defined withers, long and heavy muscles, strong shoulders; medium to long, slightly-arched, muscular neck; solidly-built legs with tough hooves
Colors: Brown, black, bay, gray, chestnut, roan
Common Uses: Harness racing, pleasure riding, trail riding, dressage; as sport horse in eventing, show hunter, show jumping; as light buggy horses by the Amish people
Health: Some Standardbreds are known to suffer from problems with joints and bones
Gaited: Yes; a racing gait called the trot, a two-beat lateral gait known as the pace, and another one called the canter
Popular Traits: Strength, stamina, agility, versatility
Feeding/Diet: Grass, hay, whole or crimped oats, steamed or soaked whole barley, cracked or crushed corn
Ancestors: Thoroughbred, Hackney, Morgan, Norfolk Trotter, Canadian Pacer, Narragansett Pacer

name: Peruvian Paso
Colors: Chestnut, brown, black, bay, buckskin, gray, roan, dun or palomino with white markings on the legs and face.
Popular Traits: Balance, smoothness, brio, endurance.
Feeding/Diet: Hay, grain, grass, shrubs.
Common Use: Pleasure riding, parades, horse exhibitions, dressage shows, trail and endurance riding.
Physical description: Sturdy, muscular, powerful build; deep chest; strongly arched neck; short back; quiet tail. Stallions possess larger neck and broader chest than the mares.
Gait: Four-beat, lateral gait (known as paso llano) — left hind, left fore, right hind, right fore.

name: North Swedish Horse
Colors: Available in all solid colors including gray, black, dun, chestnut, palomino, buckskin, brown
Common Uses: Work, endurance
Popular Traits: Low care and feeding cost, versatile, strong and hardy, easily maintainable
Feeding/Diet: General horse diets consisting of hay, grass, grains, vegetables, etc.
Health Problems: Generally a healthy breed. No breed-specific health issues. Owners must ensure to maintain a healthy lifestyle and regular vet checkups
Behavioral Characteristics: Loyal, willing to work, intelligent, fun loving, easy going, easily trainable, obedient temperament with a docile disposition, cooperative
Physical Descriptions/Traits: Both stallions and mares have a large head with long ears; low wither with a deep chest; their neck is thick but short that ends in sloping shoulders; they have a deep body with a long back side; rounded quarters with a sloping croup; their legs are short, with substantial bone; the mane and the tail are dense and abundant

name: Florida Cracker
Colors: Black, gray, grullo, roan, bay, dun, chestnut, etc.
Common Uses: Work, general riding, endurance, traditional western ranching pursuits
Popular Traits: Endurance capabilities, disease-resistance, easily maintainable, multi-talented
Feeding/Diet: General horse diet consisting of hay, grass, grains, vegetables, etc.
Ancestors: Iberian horse, Chickasaw horse, Andalusians, Spanish sorraia and North African barb horses
Health Problems: Generally healthy, no known breed-specific diseases
Temperamental Characteristics: Moderate, tenacious, mild, gentle, loyal, intelligent
Physical Descriptions: Well-defined head;  well-spaced, alert, dark eyes with a white sclera, someties gray or blue; narrow neck without excessive crest; proportionate back part; medium to narrow chest with well spring ribs; sloping, long, smooth-muscled, shoulders that are laid back; sloping and short croup with a low-set tail; body’s under line longer than top line
